newsitem.title: USA: PG&E to sell $57 mln stake in gas pipeline.
newsitem.headline: PG&E to sell $57 mln stake in gas pipeline.

text.p: Pacific Gas and Electric Company said on Thursday it agreed to sell the Sacramento Municipal Utility District (SMUD) a portion of PG&E's natural gas pipeline transmission system for $57 million.
PG&E plans to sell SMUD about 80 million cubic feet (MMcf) of natural gas a day in two PG&E lines with an option for an additional 10 MMcf per day on each line.
One line, dubbed 300, is a main transmission line delivering gas from the California/Arizona border, and the second, line 401, is a main line delivering gas from the California/Oregon border.

"This partnership will reduce our investment costs as well as our overhead costs, which will mean savings for our natural gas customers in the future," said Jack Jenkins-Stark, PG&E senior vice president and general manager of gas supply.
SMUD will use the natural gas to power three cogeneration electric power plants it currently operates or has under construction.
Under the plan, PG&E will continue to operate and maintain the jointly owned pipelines.
SMUD will pay PG&E an annual fee for these services.
"This purchase assures SMUD reliable deliveries of natural gas from both the Northern and Southern California borders," said Jan Schori, SMUD general manager.
"Up to 100 million cubic feet per day of natural gas can be transported under this purchase, which takes advantage of SMUD's new local transmission pipeline here in Sacramento," Schori added.
The agreement is subject to approval by the California Public Utilities Commission.
